title: Complex Event Processing and Data Mining for Smart Cities

author: Alexandra Moraru, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: The title of my presentation is quite general because I'll be talking in general about complex event processing and smart cities.
And then I will present some concrete results on a particular scenario that we choose on real life data 222 to see.
To see how to combine data mining and complex event processing.
So I will start with these pictures showing some general scenarios.

Actually this one is from audio system sensor web enablement initiatives, so it's about sensors which can be for traffic monitoring, health monitoring, industrial processes, building monitoring, and I'm showing this because I was working before with semantic sensor networks, so I was very interested in sensor networks and now when I started reading about smart cities, I thought that actually.
This is the same thing.
Just that it's all about how to make things interoperable to integrate them, to make them more automatic so that they can deliver the results faster and more in a more useful way.
So the outline of my presentation.
I will start with the short introduction of an event processing and smart cities.
Then I'll talk about specific use case that we chose, and I will present here the data collection and analysis data pre processing the learning of Association rules and then some final conclusions.
Maybe emphasis is not so much on the on the mining parts that this is more like an example.
Yes, yes could be anything else so.
The experiments were done in order to see if we can apply fast data mining for detecting events for finding events that will be then applied for complex event processing.
So as I will say.

Now, so even processing is any form of computing that performs operational on events, and it can have many application domains, so environmental monitoring using sensor networks, so logistics and building building management based on RFID technology.
In financial markets we have the trading algorithms which are well developed by now.
And there can be other ideas as well.
And here an event is anything that can that happens or is observed as being as happening.
And if we say complex event processing then we deal with complex events.
But this complex events are nothing else but the abstraction of other events.
So composition of similar events.
And the central piece in this event, processing is the processing engine which basically derives more complex events.
Or it applied applies different event patterns on on streams of incoming data.
And now finally I go to the event patterns which specify how the streams of events should be processed, and one of the one of the surprises for me is that although data mining is.
Has a lot of work on on pattern detection, recognition.
So on the other work which deals with complex event processing, they'd never mention it and all the time when they say event patterns, well, they magically appear.
This means that user has to define them or you do some data mining before and you find your patterns and then then you enter them in there.
But the although I believe it's a strong relation between data mining and complex human processing, this is not yet very well present in the research papers.
So here is a high level overview of what complex event pattern means processing means.
And I use this picture because I believe it's very well known in the CP community, so it's a.
High level overview and it's simple, no complications.

So here we have the complex event processing engine which basically takes the streams of events coming from the event event sources which can be sensors or news or everything that the stream it applies.
The event patterns which the user defines, or in this case we want that the machine finds them and then it sends to some event consumers or it can be in a loop.
Like the complex event, go back and so on.
So now the second general view for this is.
It's about smart cities, so.
When we talk about smart cities, we might refer to economy, people, governance, mobility, environment and living.
So these are six topics and identified in one of the studies and out of these six we we chose mobility, which refers to transport and how it is supporting transportation services.

Another definition would mean in the IBM's view Smart City requirements refer to optimizing limited resources and to efficiently and effectively deliver city service, and this means to support the collaboration and coordination between cities ad agencies.
So between like in this case, water management, transportation, and buildings.
So if we have some construction buildings that would affect transportation and maybe even water management, all these should collaborate and know about each other.
And of course it it means to apply different technologies, data sharing and integration, business rules, communication channels and so on.
Uh, and.
On the use case that we chose to do some experimental work, we choose the City of London and we thought of finding patterns for appearance of traffic.
Disruptions correlated to cultural events happening in the city.
And further further work will imply also using usage of social media.
In all this story.
The possible sources of data which we are interested in is traffic, data, weather data, cultural events, which means concerts or different gatherings.
For conferences, sales, sports events and so on.
I just tried to classify them in with the name, not just events because defense is everything events involving people.
Yeah, yeah, maybe that's better.

OK, So what we've done is we we crowd some data from for the traffic data use traffic for London, which is a service offering different date about the traffic and particularly I took the life Rd disruptions reports.
Then for weather I used the current conditions and that's the service the underground weather.
What was providing date and then for the social events it was they were taken from eventful.

And the data used was for a period of one month from 16 July to 16 of August, and here we have the update intervals for all these sources sources, so they're not very much the most updated one was the road disruptions every five minutes.
But yeah, they tend to repeat also in these updates there not necessarily new events happening.
So a bit of insight into the data for the road disruptions.
The properties analyzed were so we had start and end time some location details.

The time of last update because an event can appear more times until it finish finishes, then some types vary 10 category and we had a total of 2300 events happening for a month, which I'm I'm not sure I will.
I will check with other sources, but for me it seems a bit low for London number of events.
Yes, 2300 events in a mountain, London.
Yeah, maybe it's right.
Let's say it's right.
So this is, this is what the source reported.
Maybe there were more, but not all of them were reported.
That that's my assumption.
And then regarding the categories, so each of these events is labeled with the category, so it can be work, which means works on the road accident incident.
Another cause were actually the ones we hoped to find an explanation for.
So other cause means also the traffic jams.
Then for weather conditions, it was the report was for the whole area and it included temperature, wind, speed and some short description.
Clear Rainier so on.
But what was missing is precipitation data.
So if how much is raining or it's true that?
But yeah.
From the data collected, probably other services would provide it.
Then the social events are described by time, location, category and out of this there I believe.
Around 25 categories and the most frequent funding is music performing guards other than single social sports and so on.
And for this period of time there were over almost 6000 events in more than 1500 locations.
So this is one month right?
Yes, yes.
So from this point of view, London is a good look.
It's a good use case because it has many social events happening there.
Nothing, yeah.
Yeah.
I also looked a bit to the traffic events and yeah there are some how the numbers are somehow expected.
So during the week there are more events than in the weekend and during the day, so it's actually morning afternoon and evening, night morning and afternoon afternoon there are more.
More events
So what has been done with all the data actually?
So it first it was received from the API's of the various sources.
Then I used the Q minor for integration and preprocessing, so its source was had the custom adapter and then later was put together and then.
In using Q minor, I prepared the final data set for which was used in Vega.
So the final data set.
So for each traffic event different attributes were calculated.
Up to.
Here, yeah, there are the ones that related strictly from the traffic data.
Then I was calculating or maybe I was saying I was looking.
If there is a traffic event nearby or if there are if there is a social event nearby and this is the weather data.
And here are the cultural events so for each.
Of the IF there was an event nearby, then also the category of it was mentioned.
If with true or false.
You have also location.
Yes, this location Maps down to Geo coordinates.
Yes, yes, everything is latitude.
Lanja tude actually actually for the yeah, but for the traffic it's the UK standard but it can be translated to let it injected.
OK, so near what nearby event means.
It's an event situated at the predefined maximum distance and time interval related to the current event.
So I tried, I checked.
Sorry.
I checked for.
Different distances, so 500 meters in one kilometer and different time interval differences.
So one hour or three hour, 4 hours.
And this is the number of traffic events which are nearby of a specific event.
So for this data set 31.
Instances had the nearby traffic event and 230 instances had the nearby social event, so I continued with this data set.
And I used a priority from the account.
There were some crashing problems when although the data set was not big, somehow still doesn't work with it.
So in the end I had to do two sets of experiments.
First I reduced the number of attributes, eliminating the categories, but in this case there weren't really relevant rules found, just that.
Maybe like if it's?
Afternoon then the severity is moderate because all had the severity moderate.
The rules were really not not good, and then I did, the other would reduce the number of instances because the goal was actually to find the correlation between these social events and the.
Traffic events, so I reduced only to the number of instances which had the nearby social event.
With.
Yes, it's there is some nearby social event there, so there are 230 instances with this case.
And then again here.
The rules were not surprising, but maybe like cultural events are more often happening in the evening.
Yes.
Or that some cultural categories are related, like single socials, which I'm not yet sure what that means or and performing arts then it means it's also some music event.
So the conclusion?
Yeah, but I didn't checked.
I didn't really check into the data to see what kind of events are with discotheque.
So there is no clear evidence of the influence of cultural events over Rd events.
This is one of the conclusions, but possible explanation is that data is a bit too little.
One month it's not so much and also over from this one month.
There were some missing values for the duration of events, so you didn't know when the traffic event ended.
And maybe the approximation made there was not good.
From then also defining these nearby events is a bit tricky, like maybe for some big concerts the area affected is much bigger than for smaller ones.
So yes, here here can be a bit more.

This parameters can be a bit more refined, But anyway future steps would mean integration of more data sources and also social media is specially tweets about the cultural events which would indicate how important that event is.
Also some visualization, maybe it would be good for getting a faster insight into the data.
I did tried visualization for only four.
Traffic events, but again there was nothing which you can easily see there, so.
Yeah, you can use.
Yeah OK, I will try.
And then of course, the final goal is to use some CP engines with the patterns detected.
Thank you for your attention.
